results.title: Passport to Pimlico
results.creator_credit: Sir Michael Balcon, Henry Cornelius and Ealing Studios
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Forever Ealing”.
This was the first classic Ealing comedy. An ancient document reveals that London’s Pimlico district really belongs to France. The community eager to abandon post-War constraints, particularly rationing establish their independence as a ration-free state with hilarious results. Stars Stanley Holloway, Hermione Baddeley and the wonderful Margaret Rutherford.

results.title: Passionless moments
results.brief_description: A series of suburban vignettes dealing with everyday eccentricities. Filmed in black and white, this is an early work by renowned New Zealand filmmaker Jane Campion. Through a series of alternately ironic and bizarre vignettes, the filmmaker composes a joyful celebration to the beauty of the mundane and the ordinary.

results.title: Passiona
results.brief_description: Cathy was a shy, awkward nine year old with a crush on her school teacher, Mr. Wright. Ten years later, as an attractive nineteen year old, Cathy meets him again at her cousin’s birthday party. He develops an interest in her and her memories of him are stirred. Through her romantic childhood eyes, she relives school days. As the night progresses, however, she faces the reality of her teacher and the deceptions wrought by both passion and memory.

results.title: Passion fish
results.creator_credit: Atchafalaya Films Inc, Sarah Green, Maggie Renzi and John Sayles
results.brief_description: Mary McDonnell is May-Alice, star of a popular day-time soap, who was on her way to a leg waxing session when she was knocked down by a mad taxi-driver. Now confined to a wheelchair, she has only one option left - to return to the Bayou she so defiantly left as a sassy teen. Hiding out in the house of her long dead parents, May-Alice becomes the patient from hell, terrorising a series of nurses and driving each and every one of them from the house. Then Chantelle, a no-nonsense nurse from Chicago, arrives. Chantelle couldn’t be more different than May-Alice and it seems she too will be given her marching orders. Then, unexpectedly, differences are put aside, secrets emerge, old friends drift into their lives and each finds an unlikely romance as they give themselves up to the forces of fate and friendship. Brilliant performances by the cast make this film a rewarding and worthwhile experience.

results.title: Passion (TEFC)
results.brief_description: The rise and fall of a shopgirl (Pola Negri in her screen debut) who became the mistress of Louis XV in her ruthless pursuit of wealth and influence, was a landmark in German cinema, and a runaway box office success internationally. Great care was taken with historical accuracy in both costuming and design but Lubitsch’s primary interest was in character, plot and spectacle not in historical reconstruction. Although attacked by Left critics for ignoring the social and political significance of the Revolution, Lubitsch was not apolitical in his approach either in this film or subsequently. He maintains an ironic detachment which allows for complexity of characterisation and in his own way here portrays the realities of wealth and power. This silent film is accompanied with English intertitles.

results.title: Passion (1999)
results.creator_credit: Matt Carroll, Film Finance Corporation Australia, New South Wales Film and Television Office and Peter Duncan
results.brief_description: London, 1914, and Australian pianist and composer Percy Grainger (Richard Roxburgh) is living in London under the management of his mother, Rose (Barbara Hershey). Mother and son share an “unnatural” bond, questioned for being incestuous. Grainger is overpowered by his creative abilities at the expense of ordinary sensibilities. He has a passion for music, passion for life and sex, blatantly disregarding conventions in regards to what people expect him to play. Most significantly, he derives the most passion and pleasure from his propensity for sado-masochism, the one thing he and his mother do not agree on. Percy is introduced to pianist Karen Holten (Emily Woof) to tutor, but also to absorb the feelings he has for his mother. Rose hopes Karen will be a counterfoil to his perverse tendencies, but she is sorely mistaken. Musings on the differences between lust, admiration, friendship and what it means to love are also covered in this biopic of a musician and painter equally known for his peccadillos and fondness for leisurewear. Based on the play “Percy & Rose” written by Rob George.

results.title: Passing through Sweden
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Joseph Koenig, John Kemeny and Martin Duckworth
results.brief_description: A film critic of one of Sweden’s daily newspapers says of this film by Martin Duckworth, “Never before have I seen a film that so intensely interpreted the experience of Swedish surroundings … an atmosphere film” in which all the expression is in the pictures.

results.title: Passing through
results.brief_description: A young family on their way to visit relatives pass through an old gold mining town. As the woman begins to delve into memories of her childhood, the family leave to continue their journey. Has she missed the opportunity to discover the secrets of the past?
